Award.AwardTitle: Dissecting the anatomy of regulatory divergence
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Ilya Ruvinsky

Proposal #: 1355093

Title: Dissecting the anatomy of regulatory divergence?

Gene expression patterns change as species evolve, and it is clear that some changes in gene expression are visible as changes in genetically-encoded traits. Less well-understood is the observation that visibly conserved traits in different species are sometimes specified by divergent gene regulatory mechanisms. The goal of the work proposed here is to understand how changes in gene expression influence traits in different species. Results from this study will not only impact our understanding of the evolution of developmental mechanisms, but also our understanding of the discovery of broader evolutionary trends. Dr. Ruvinsky will incorporate findings of this work into his teaching of undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Chicago as well as to science teachers of Chicago Public Schools. Research in Dr. Ruvinsky?s laboratory will involve undergraduate and graduate students who will be trained in experimental and computational approaches central to this proposal. The PI and other members of the laboratory will present their findings at a variety of scientific meetings.

The Ruvinsky Laboratory at the University of Chicago has established the gene unc-47 in Caenorhabditis nematodes as a model system for the study of gene regulatory evolution. Despite an apparently conserved expression pattern among these nematode species, the mechanisms that control unc-47 have diverged. The PI proposes three aims. First, Dr. Ruvinsky will dissect in detail the divergence of cis-regulation of the unc-47 gene in Caenorhabditis. Combining comparative and functional approaches, this work will provide a detailed picture of changes, possibly at the single-nucleotide resolution, that led to the divergence of regulatory mechanisms, while preserving the expression pattern. Second, using both standard and state-of-the-art molecular genetic methods, Dr. Ruvinsky will identify compensatory mutations in trans(cription) factors that permitted cis-regulatory divergence of unc-47 without changes to the expression pattern of the gene. Finally, Dr. Ruvinsky will determine the generality of the principles of regulatory divergence inferred from the unc-47 locus. Several genes have been identified that retain conserved expression in different species, while being regulated in subtly different ways. The goal of this aim is to test whether the rules governing changes in unc-47 regulation apply to other genes. Together these experiments promise to provide a highly detailed mechanistic view of gene regulatory evolution and thus contribute to the study of Evo-Devo.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gene regulation is central to organismal function. When, where, and how much each gene is expressed is determined by the binding of proteins, called transcription factors, to their binding sites that are stretches of a few DNA nucleotides. Arrays of binding sites, commonly referred to as enhancers, are located in the vicinity of genes they regulate. Although much is known about gene regulation in general, organization of most enhancers remains elusive. This is because for most genes only a few transcription factors that regulate them are known and discovering them all is currently prohibitively laborious. Computational approaches could greatly speed up discovery, but most binding sites are too short for functional ones to be distinguished from those that spuriously occur in the genome. One possible approach to learning more about the composition and organization of enhancers is to compare sequences that regulate cognate genes in different species because, functionally relevant portions of enhancers are thought to be preferentially conserved in evolution. We carried out this work in a model organism C. elegans, a system that permits a range of precise experimental manipulations. Specifically, we tested whether enhancers from a variety of nematode species could direct expression in C. elegans and how well this expression corresponded to the expression pattern driven by the native C. elegans enhancers of cognate genes. We made several discoveries that were published in open-access journals. When testing enhancers from closely related relatives of C. elegans, we found gross conservation of expression patterns (compared to the native C. elegans genes), but also erroneous expression that followed specific rules. Overall enhancer sequence conservation was not a reliable indicator of functional conservation. These conclusions were confirmed by experiments with enhancers from nematodes distantly related to C. elegans. We found that despite overall sequence similarity being no greater than expected by chance alone, these enhancers nevertheless could direct at least partially correct expression in C. elegans. We demonstrated that this functional conservation was due to binding sites of transcription factors known to regulate these genes in C. elegans. Overall, our results improve understanding of how gene regulation evolves and suggest that comparative genomics of enhancers (attempts to infer sequence functions from cross-species comparisons) need to be primarily focused on analysis of constellations of functional binding sites. In the course of this work, we made several unexpected discoveries concerning the role of social signals in regulating aspects of organismal development and physiology. Several of these findings have already been published, others constitute a major direction of current research in the lab. All projects provided an enriching environment for training of young scientists, including members of traditionally underrepresented minorities. Several now pursue research carriers as faculty or independent researchers in academia and in industry. Others continue advanced training in STEM fields. As part of the Broader Impacts mission, we engaged high school biology teachers and students via a combination of teaching, laboratory demonstrations, and conducting research.
